This one is for my autism mama’s

 I know some people hat that term, but I don’t. It represents a piece of who I am and it’s brought to me a community of the most amazing women

And what I’ve gained the most here from social media is the relationship with other autism moms

How special it is to have one another, to be able to talk with and support each other no matter the distance 

I know often this path feels lonely and hard and mostly it’s because we are working so hard for others to love and accept  our kids 

We need each other and we are all out there fighting the same battle for our children❤️

#autismmom #autismacceptance #asd #autismawareness #womensupportingwomen #inclusion #love #dailyinspiration #dailymotivation #disability #specialneedsmom #motherhood #family #autistic #autismfamily

Hudson is autistic and has been singing a lot lately, which is so awesome to hear his little voice more and more!

But the songs he sing often seem random and sometimes we don’t know where they come from 

This song however, is a song his older brother wrote for a school project over a year ago

It’s crazy how Hudson’s mind works and what he can remember from such a long time ago

I always say I wish I could just get inside his head and see how he sees and experience what he feels and although I know I will never get that experience it is nice to be able to hear bits and snippets of what goes on inside that head of his☺️

#autism #autistic #wecanchangetheworld #love #autismawareness #autismacceptance #inclusion #dailyinspiration #bekind #autismfamily #disability #dailymotivation #autismmom

Hudson is autistic and has always has such a special bond with his older brother Ledger

Ledger has always been his comfort 

There’s something different between siblings when one has a disability I think

When there is a lack of verbal communication between siblings they seem to find a different way to communicate 

It’s a look, a touch, a hug, a laugh 

It means so much more and brings a deep meaningful connection 

I love the bond between all of my boys, and they are all different in the best ways

But the connection between these two has always brought tears to my eyes🥹

#autismawareness #autismsiblings #love #brothers #specialneeds #autistic #asd #autismfamily #disability #specialneedssiblings #autismmom #inclusion #dailyinspiration #bekind #dailymotivation  #autismacceptance

Sometimes as a parent of an autistic child it can feel like we can’t or aren’t connecting with our kiddo the way we’d like

It sometimes just makes us feel sad and it’s hard

But what I have learned over the years with Hudson is that our connection is still strong even without words

Yes, it looks different and has to be approached in different ways then it is with my Nuero typical kids

It has taken me years to really learn that when I join Hudson in the things he loves to do, no matter what that is, he responds to me

He laughs, he looks at me, he sings, he grabs me

This is how we connect!

It simple, it’s  beautiful and it’s strong

How do you connect with your autistic kiddo?

Life skills! 

I feel like not enough emphasis is placed on learning and teaching life skills

I mean the emphasis of Hudson’s “Life Skills” class is academics…knowing his site words and addition and subtraction 

But what about making friends? What about learning how to shop, get dressed, order food, dress appropriately, greet a person, I could go on and on

I do think academics are important but I do not think that they are the MOST  important 

And I think that the best way to learn life skills is to be WITH people (our peers) who can model them most appropriately 

Let’s not forget that LIFE SKIILS are just as (if not more) important then academics 😉

What a morning!

In the past, Christmas seem to overwhelm Hudson. He would appear uninterested and would mostly roam around as we opened our presents 

But not today!

Hudson was genuinely excited all morning!

He didn’t seem to care what was in his presents but either way he showed that he loved opening the wrappings☺️

Honestly I think Hudson just loved being with his family, doing what his brothers were doing 

I think the miracle of today was Hudson’s awareness and overall presence 

His growth over the past year has just been incredible and today was a beautiful example of just how far he’s come❤️

I’ve been in meeting after meeting where I am told how behind Hudson is academically 

I am aware of Hudson’s academic deficiencies however I do not see them as the utmost importance 

Not only do I know that we have not discovered a way for Hudson to tell us what he knows but it is also not a reason for Hudson to not be included with his peers

It is my belief that the skills that Hudson learns from inclusion/ being with his peers are some of the most important 

Hudson learning to play and connect with others are much more important to me right now then having him learn to write his name

Academics are important and we will always continue to teach Hudson but they are not the most important, nor are the an excuse to keep are kids from being with their peers

#inclusion #play #socialskills #love #autismawareness #autismacceptance #asd #autistic #autismmom #lifeskills #specialeducation #specialneeds #specialneedsmom #autismfamily #dailyinspiration #advocatelikeamother #advocate

I found this quote and truly felt like it was from Hudson 

So many times I have seen him try to be like his peers, to play with them, to just interact 

It is one of the most difficult things for me to watch as his mom

Thankfully, I have also experienced miracles as several of his peers have walked beside him seeing him as he is

These moments are truly beautiful and moments I pray for daily

“Don’t walk in front of me, I may not follow
Don’t walk behind me, I may not lead
Walk beside me and be my friend”❤️

#autismawareness #inclusion #love #autismacceptance #beafriend #bekind #autismmom #autistic #specialneeds #autismfamily #lifequotes #teachthemyoung #motherhood #boymom #dailyinspiration #dailymotivation

Often our kids just need to go and adjust in their own way and in their own timing

This process you see in this video of Hudson going from being alone and completely uninvolved to putting himself right in the middle of the group took about an hour and an half

It wasn’t 5-10 minutes, it took a good amount of time but it was just his way and what he needed

It really got me thinking though

How often is Hudson, and other kids like Hudson, told in schools “you have 2 minutes and then we’re going to…..” (insert activity)

I wonder if we stopped puttering time limits on our kids, stepped back, made them feel safe and comfortable, and then slowly guided them along when they showed us they were ready, what the results would be

Cause I bet we would be pretty surprised in what we would see!

Today had me in tears…

First, because Hudson completely initiated playing with this little boy at the park, he followed his lead, imitated him and it was remarkable🥹

But also because this little boy truly included Hudson in his play. He waited for him, gave him high fives, looked at him in his eyes, and slowly and patiently guided him around the playground. my heart could have exploded 🥹

Inclusion is not grand gestures or forced friendship. Inclusion is subtle, intentional and natural,
especially when we are young. 

Please teach your children to be curious about those who seem different. Teach them to be patient, gentle and kind. You never know when it’s your child who will change someone’s life just by being kind. 

Also, yes, I was the weirdo mom filming my kid playing in the park🫣

#inclusion #lifechanging #autismawareness #autismacceptance #dailyinspiration #autismmom #disability #specialneeds #play #bekind #dailymotivation #love #kindness #autistic #sensoryplay

Inclusion at its best may not look like much from the outside perspective 

But that’s really how you know it’s working!

It’s the everyday, full time, intentional actions that truly make others feel a part of something 

Too often we put a child in a typical classroom for 30 minutes a day and call it inclusion

Is it though?

To me inclusion is to be an actual part of a group, classroom or community… not just a visitor or guest

And if you think about what that looks like, it’s not forced friendships or big grand gestures it’s really the small acts of kindness, the high fives, the hellos, the natural play that kids do so well

Inclusion, in my eyes, at its best is often invisible to the outsider and that’s when you know you’re doing something right.

I often feel like we have an expectation of what inclusion really is

It seems to be done in small increments of time, trying to force a social interaction or a group activity to either get a result or just to say “yep, we do inclusion here”

But what I have found over the years is that inclusion doesn’t have a time limit or expectations 

True inclusion is really a collaboration of worlds that are constantly learning from one another because they care and want to!

It’s intentional, non judgmental and constant

I recently attended an Autism Conference at an University held by many of the professionals currently in the field.

One of the presenters was currently in the mist of her research which was for suicide prevention among autistics. She has and continues to interview autistic people, mainly teens and young adults

Of the many interviews she has done these were among the most common feelings reported to her 

It broke my heart

I felt so many emotions, I was overwhelmed and broken

After the session the audience (filled with many concerned parents just like myself) asked some questions like “what can we do, the doctors have turned us away for mental health issues saying it’s just my sons autism”

The presenter sadly stated over and over how much more research is needed in order to help the autism community, but didn’t have any answers

After the session I sat in a quiet place and thought, why are we only looking at reactive strategies for suicide prevention…there has to be proactive things we can do to help our autistic children not feel this way

And to me the answer was so clear

It starts with inclusion 

True inclusion in our schools and communities, and from a young age

We have to stop excluding kids who learn and act “different” and we have to stop with the idea that a child needs to be like their peers to be included

We need our children to grow up knowing that Inclusion is not a privilege, it’s a right

We have to educate those who educate our kids

We have to TEACH kids that it’s ok to look, act, and behave differently 

We need to TEACH inclusion

We need our kids to not feel alone, unimportant, weird, and to know that this world was made exactly for them

I know this is not the answer to everything, but I do believe it’s the right place to start

#inclusion #autistic #love #autismacceptance #autismawareness #dailyinspiration #advocatelikeamother #advocate #autismmom #autism #specialeducation #disability #specialneeds #autismfamily #bethechange #teic #suicideprevention

I often feel like there is a stigma about stimming

I have experienced many situations in which parents or teachers try to stop stimming 

But you know what, stimming It’s actually good!

Stimming or self stimulatory behavior helps autistic people self regulate 

It makes their body feel good and it helps them in over stimulating environments or situations 

and it should never be discouraged or shamed

let’s teach our kids about stimming and what is means

Let’s make it the new normal✌🏽

#stimming #autismawareness #autismacceptance #love #autistic #autismmom #advocatelikeamother #advocate #inclusion #dailyinspiration #bekind #instagood #specialneeds #specialeducation

Tonight I took the boys to watch Cameron do a show

I knew it was risky with Hudson as he often gets scared at movie theaters or live performances, I think  it’s the different noise frequencies that he doesn’t like, but I still wanted to try

When we got there Hudson wouldn’t go into the room, as I had expected

But what I didn’t expect is that as Cameron’s name was announced Hudson ran up to the curtain and peeked in

He watched his dad sing and play guitar and he jumped and stimmed the entire time☺️

But the best part was to hear Cameron say “that’s my son” when Hudson got a little loud🥹

He didn’t ignore it (which would have been fine and what I think most people would expect) 

But he called Hudson out and brought attention to his autistic son in the best way possible 

The crowd cheered and the show went on

I will never forget this moment 🥹

I typically don’t mind when people stare at Hudson, they are usually just curious or smile kindly 

But I do wonder how Hudson feels about it, and it’s something I just dont know

So, I started to jump or skip with him whenever he did 

And let me tell you, the joy on his face 
EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.  let me know that he liked me joining in his happiness and excitement 

and now, it’s our thing

our entire family jumps with Hudson

It’s how we connect with Hudson in times of excitement 

So, feel free to stare☺️

Today in an IEP meeting I was told that my son “is very low, I mean he can’t even write an H”

I couldn’t believe that an educator, who works for the district, was using these words and talking about my autistic son this way

I realized that she truly didn’t understand my son or kids with disabilities, for that matter

This verbiage is extremely harmful and I pray that this has never been said in Hudson’s presence 

We need to do better especially as educators 

We don’t know what we don’t know

But now you know

Tonight we went to the park for a community picnic, just a bunch of neighbors making burgers and hot dogs

A few kids from Hudson’s school instantly came over and started talking to me and Hudson

And then something I wasn’t expecting happened

The stayed around

They followed and talked to Hudson for an entire hour and an half

They pushed him on swings, chased him, asked him questions 

They didn’t seem to mind Hudson spitting and joined in with him stimming 

I hid my tears behind my sunglasses and knew they may never fully understand what their actions truly meant for me as a mother

My worst fears were being wiped away for that moment, kids being kids and their kindness was so pure 

It’s moments like this that keep pushing me forward making the fight of changing systems so worthwhile

Tonight was a good one🥹

#autismawareness #autismacceptance #autistic #love #kindness #autismmom #autismfamily #bekind #advocatelikeamother #inclusion #dailyinspiration #joy #thebestisyettocome

Being an advocate for Hudson is one of the most important jobs in my life

It’s hard, exhausting, worthwhile, joyous, defeating all mixed together at the same time, all the time🤪

But advocating is also just showing up everyday

Showing up to school, showing up to IEP meetings, showing up to therapies, to doctor appointments, showing up for the extra curricular activities, showing up when you feel like you don’t have enough, showing up when you feel like you can’t,
and for me, it’s just showing up for Hudson EVERYDAY!

And that is enough❤️

I get asked pretty regularly how I spend time with my twins when Hudson needs so much support and just the guilt of it all

It was especially hard when Hudson was little and I was just learning what it meant for my son to be autistic

I had to learn how to parent three little boys who all had different needs, one with much more support than the others 

But my husband and I just decided that we were going to just DO things 

Knowing it would be easier to stay home or let a friend or a different family member take the twins to their games and events 

We made a choice to just show up

And it means being creative, multitasking, having people stare, asking for help 

And knowing that sometimes we fail

But we just always made a conscious effort to show up

And so far that’s been enough☺️

I was going to make this a sweet moment with sweet music…but then I didn’t it😏😉😂.
.

But one thing I’ve heard over and over straight from the mouths of autistic teens and adults is how they would be shamed or punished for stimming when they were younger 

They felt like they needed to hide or repress it and in that act would immediately loose what ever joy they were feeling in that moment 

 Stimming is something we ALL do just in different ways and somewhere along the way we decided what social appropriate stimming was and wasn’t 

Joining in our children, friends, and classmates with autism stims can be the best way to connect and build authentic relationships

It also promotes inclusion and allows us to SHOW acceptance 

Plus it’s really fun 😉

Life is not always easy and we often don’t see the struggles that people are going through

I get asked often “how do you manage time with your twins when you have an autistic child” “don’t you feel guilty”

I definitely use to think these things and truthfully these thoughts consumed me

I cried in my bathroom a lot and it was really hard

 what I didn’t see during that time though was that I was actually growing

I was learning and I was getting stronger

these are things I don’t think we can see in the moment which tends to make those moments in life so much harder

I know I didn’t feel strong, I actually felt incredibly weak

but that’s the joy that comes with time and growth

I was growing, changing, and learning every day! 

It was hard but I wouldn’t change a moment of it because it made me to be able to be the advocate I am for all my boys

Those tough years 100% made me strong enough to stand up for Hudson in an IEP meeting, to have the energy and time to be the twins soccer coach, to play and be the mom for my boys

Growth and strength are continuous 

I don’t feel them everyday 

but because I can look back to those especially difficult times in my life I know that I am stronger then I think

and that’s what I try to always remember

I’ve been working with autistic children for well over 15 years now, the last 7 years have been mixed with also being a mother to an autistic child

But I regret to say that it hasn’t been until recently that I’ve seen where we’ve gone wrong in helping our autistic children

Somehow we have come to a place where we dismiss so much of non verbal communication, which I find so interesting since we’ve been told that 80% of all communication is nonverbal, in all of us

But then why do we not honor those who do not have meaningful speech non verbal communication???

Because it looks different then we’d like it to?

I think it’s actually because we have not been trained to really listen in the way that our non speakers do

From an mother of a non speaking autistic son, let’s change our ways in how we listen to our autistic children and let’s teach others to do the same

We got a bit spontaneous and decided we were just going to do it and go camping

It’s something my husband and I talked about wanting to do with the boys for a few years now

We kept putting it off because there is always the worry of so many “what if’s” especially with Hudson 

What if he hates it, what if he’s too loud all night, what if he runs off, what if he doesn’t eat anything 

These are all valid worries but we just have no idea until we try

And I’m so glad we just tried!

Hudson seemed to enjoy every minute just being with his family, being with his big brothers, doing exactly what they did

Hudson is 9 now and it’s important that we at least give him the opportunities to try new things

And if they don’t go well, they don’t go well and we move on and maybe try again later

But as his mom, I owe him at least trying☺️

and how I deal with the mom guilt of it all

Regression is a part of autism

I don’t really understand it but it’s always hard for me to see as a mother of an autistic child

A few years ago I was talking with another mom about regression and she shared with me this term “the slingshot effect “

It’s not a medical term and if you look it up you probably won’t find anything

 but to me it made so much sense

So often Hudson would have these regressions and I’d try so hard to understand them and help him. I hated thinking and seeing him move backwards. But when I started to pay attention, I noticed that Hudson would also have huge periods of growth shortly after. Whether it be a week or months later it always came!

I realized that I would get so stuck in these regression moments but never properly celebrated his growth

Right now we are seeing some set backs in Hudson and it’s hard, it’s always hard seeing your child struggle

But I remind myself that growth WILL follow!

It is ok and really it’s part of life

I will be by his side always helping him through his toughest days 

But I will also be there celebrating his biggest victories

How we talk about our kids matters and the language we use matters!

“He’s so high” or “he’s low” are not appropriate terms to use when referring to an autistic persons cognitive ability, yet unfortunately is used frequently within schools, clinics, and medical offices

I don’t believe that those who use these terms intend any kind of harm but are more just uninformed 

But imagine being a non speaking person and hearing others talk about you without being able to give your own input about YOURSELF 

When in doubt ALWAYS presume competence

it’s the very least we can do

LISTENING DOESN’T HAVE A LOOK

I heard this phrase as I sat in my S2C practitioner class last week and it hit me hard

often people speak in front of our children as if they can’t hear, or as if they’re not listening 

Autistic people have been spoken about rather than spoken to for probably most of their lives, especially our non speakers

Non speakers have been telling us for years that they ARE LISTENING 

In fact non speakers LISTEN better than speakers

So please remember the next time someone says to your child “let me see your eyes” or speaks about them rather than TO them that 

LISTENING DOESN’T HAVE A LOOK

And I promise, our autistic non speaking kids are ALWAYS listening and understanding!!

Every time I take Hudson into a store I ask him “do want to get in a cart or walk?”

And 99% of the time he’ll say “cart”

We often get some looks, which is fine but the other day we had three people make a comment about how big he was to be in there 

They weren’t especially mean comments but they weren’t nice

But what I noticed was that never had anyone smiled and just said “hi” to him

I LOVE that Hudson likes to ride in the cart because it keeps him safe! I don’t have to worry about him running off and losing him as I shop

But I also love that that’s what he likes to do, at least for now

So, if you happen to see a bigger kid doing what you think is “smaller kid activities” please just be kind

Kindness goes a long way☺️

So often I hear how poor Hudson’s communication skills are when really what they mean is that he can’t speak

His communication skills are there and if you are really watching and paying attention, he is communicating ALL the time

ALL of us use non verbal communication to communicate

In fact, experts say that 70-93% off all communication is non verbal

So let’s remember that when we are talking about communication with our non speaking kiddos

They ARE communicating, ALL the time

But we do need to be paying attention ❤️

When I talk about S2C (spell to communicate) this is the question I get asked the most

S2C is all about training up the motor so the body can make purposeful movements, the cognitive is already there but it is the body that is failing to do what the mind wants to do, aka apraxia 

I hope this answers a lot of questions about the letter boards and feel free to ask me any other questions you may have about S2C🫶

Hudson’s IEP (individualized Education Plan) meeting is coming up, which is typically a area of stress for me and I know that runs true for many of us parents

I am no longer a stranger to IEP meetings now that Hudson is 9 and in the third grade 

And when it comes to his goals for the year I have learned what goals truly matter 

I now let his team know that I am not interested in Hudson working towards goals that work towards him being like his peers

because he isn’t like them and that is ok!

And over the years I have realized that hese types of goals never work 

and they are unfair to Hudson

Hudson is non speaking and autistic, he communicates, moves, and feels differently and it is not something he needs to be taught to fight against 

Instead I have learned that what makes Hudson the most successful is his when his peers are understanding of his differences

It should never be up to our very young children to change their differences just to fit in 

And what I have found is that when kids are taught at a young age about those with differences, they are exceptionally accepting!

I am a firm believer that non speaking people whether they be small kids or adults are 100% aware of when others presume competence in them or not

Hudson’s cousins have ALWAYS done this with him!

They don’t know each other well as we live in different states but EVERYTIME they visit Hudson’s interactions with them are so deep and meaningful 

It’s truly amazing 🥹

When we started Spell to Communicate (S2C) I was told that I would be met with push back from professionals, schools, people…

but I  was just so excited, we had found a way for our son to communicate 

and when I watched open spellers communicate freely I couldn’t believe that anyone could deny it

I felt such relief and hope for my son, we finally found a way for him to show us what he knows

of course I wanted to shout from the rooftops, I want every non speaker’s family to know that this works!

I thought I’d be met with excitement from everyone, especially those who work with Hudson

and I was by some

but I was also met with push back and denied access to letter boards in his school 

I realize now that yet again we are in a fight 

a fight to prove that his communication is reliable

and I am here for it😉

if I’m scared that Hudson (who is non speaking and autistic) will have to live with us forever

and truly I do not fear Hudson living with us always

Who will understand him?

these are my worries as Hudson’s mom

I think it’s so easy for us as parents of non speaking kiddos to just want them to talk!

If they could just get their words out everything would be easier 

I get it, I’ve been there!!!

But as Hudson gets older I realize that it is not speech that I really want

it is communication that I am actually desperate for

I want Hudson to be able to say how he feels, what he wants and needs

I want him to be able to express himself 

and what I really long for is conversations with him

I believe when we put our focus more on communication we take so much stress off of our kids and us

It’s communication they need

and if that’s not with their voice, that’s ok!
